At 04:48 AM 10/10/01, you wrote:
>Thank you for your help! I got some idea from you. Thanks.
>
>But if the classes and the methods I want to test are abstract, I
>can't know what will happen in the methods of the subclasses which
>extend from these abstract classes.


The only thing that JUnit really tests is the unit (hence the name), where 
a unit is usually (in my experience) a method. It doesn't test the 
relationships between methods - this is a seperate field.

To test an abstract class you'll need to create a second class that extends 
the first, with only the barest of implementations - and then test that.



>  Why I asked this question is that
>these classes I will test are a framework of our project, many of
>them are abstract classes. Our project team must follow this
>framework and extend from these abstract classes to develop our
>project. Now I was assigned to test if this framework is correct.
>What can I do?

Define correct to start with!


What do you really want to test? Junit can be used (as I mentioned above) 
to test if the individual methods in the base class(es) are doing what you 
expect - does a method called "saveFile()" really save a file, and is it 
the file you expect; does a method call "reportError(BigError myError)" 
really report myError, what happens if myError is null, or...
It won't tell you if the framework you have is correct, stable etc. It'll 
only give you confidence that the individual classes are stable and "correct".



Jim
